Title:
Continental scale patterns and predictors of fern richness
and phylogenetic diversity
Journal:
Frontiers in Genetics Evolutionary and Population
Genetics
Keywords:
Polypodiopsida, Filicopsida, Ferns, Australia,
Conservation, Evolution, Diversity, Molecular Phylogeny
Abstract:
Aim To test how fern diversity is distributed on a
broad-scale using standard and corrected richness measures as well as
phylogenetic indices; and to determine the environmental predictors of
each diversity metric. Location Australia Methods Using a dataset of
over 60,000 herbarium records for 89 genera, patterns of richness were
inferred using a standard taxon-based metric as well as a
sample-standardized richness metric (Margalef richness). A three-gene
phylogenetic tree of all the genera was constructed and combined with
the herbarium records to infer phylogenetic diversity patterns. The
latter was additionally assessed statistically through a randomization
procedure. All indices were correlated to 11 environmental variables in
a spatial statistical framework. Results A hotspot of both taxic and
phylogenetic diversity occurs in the Wet Tropics of northeastern
Australia. Although considerable diversity is distributed along the
eastern coast, some important regions of diversity are identified only
through sampled-standardized richness and the phylogenetic metric. Of
all of the metrics, annual precipitation was identified as the most
explanatory variable, in part, in agreement with global and regional
fern studies. However, precipitation was combined with a different
variable for each different metric (either topography, temperature or
radiation). Significantly high and significantly low phylogenetic
diversity were found in geographically separate areas. These separate
areas are correlated with different climatic conditions such as
seasonality in precipitation. Main conclusions The use of phylogenetic
metrics identifies additional areas of significant diversity, some of
which have not been revealed in using traditional taxonomic analyses,
suggesting that different ecological and evolutionary processes have
operated over the continent. Precipitation is critical to all measures
of diversity, and correlation of phylogenetic diversity to radiation
indicates support for the species-energy hypothesis. Our study
demonstrates that it is possible and vital to incorporate evolutionary
metrics when inferring biodiversity hotspots from large compilations of
data. â€ƒ
